urn:contentItem:5PJ4-JHH1-DY2R-2203-00000-00Big technology firms are newly in the hot seat at home;Platform regulation2017-09-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:22:56ZLexisNexisBUSINESSBig technology firms are newly in the hot seat at homePlatform regulation

Big technology firms are newly in the hot seat at home

ANTITRUST, privacy, hate speech—whenever the European Union tries to rein in tech giants, Americans accuse it of protectionism. That argument has always been simplistic, but now it is harder to make; scarcely a week passes in Washington when companies like Apple and Google are not in politicians' crosshairs.

The latest target is Facebook. Earlier this month the firm revealed that 470 accounts that appeared to be controlled from Russia had bought advertisements worth a total of $100,000 on the social network between June 2015 and May 2017. Alex Stamos, Facebook's chief security officer, said they aimed at "amplifying divisive social and political messages".

This was the first time Facebook had acknowledged that Russia may have used the social network, leading the team of Robert Mueller, the special counsel investigating possible links between Donald Trump's presidential campaign and the Russian government, to issue a search warrant to get further details. Now the Senate's intelligence committee has asked Facebook executives to testify at a public hearing. Some in Washington want to force Facebook to disclose who is behind political advertisements.

Another initiative reached the hearing stage on September 19th. The Stop Enabling Sex Traffickers Act (SESTA) is aimed at stopping online services from hosting sex-trafficking advertisements—in particular Backpage.com, a site notorious for such ads. It was set in motion by an affecting documentary, "I am Jane Doe", which chronicles the legal battles waged by sex-trafficking victims against Backpage.com.

But SESTA is also bad news for Google, which is still reeling from being made responsible for the firing in August of Barry Lynn, a prominent critic of big tech companies, from the New America Foundation, a Washington think-tank which the firm supports. Google worries, as many experts do, that SESTA will undercut section 230 of the Communications Decency Act, a statute that largely exempts online firms from liability for their users' actions and which is a big reason why the internet has been a fountain of innovation. Google cannot oppose the legislation openly because it would be seen as defending sex traffickers.

The bill also plays into the hands of some of Google's foes, who may be happy to see it weakened. Oracle, a software firm, has come out in support of SESTA. Google has fallen out with its Silicon Valley neighbour over Android, its mobile operating system; the two are now involved in a billion-dollar intellectual-property battle. Media types and academics are again discussing ways of reining in big tech companies. The authors of two critical books—"Move Fast and Break Things" by Jonathan Taplin and "World Without Mind" by Franklin Foer—are a media scholar and a former magazine editor, respectively. Luigi Zingales and Guy Rolnik, both of the University of Chicago, have called for legislation to reallocate the ownership of data created on social media to users.

The question is whether the tech backlash will result in new laws, beyond (perhaps) SESTA. Big antitrust investigations still appear far off. The nominee for antitrust chief at the Department of Justice, Makan Delrahim, yet to be confirmed, seems most interested in protecting American firms from "discriminatory antitrust enforcement" abroad, not in attacking monopoly power at home. Much will depend on how the companies react. They need to do more than invest heavily in lobbying. Instead they should strengthen their infrastructure for policing their platforms and be much more transparent, argues Nick Sinai, a lecturer at Harvard University and an investor at Insight Venture Partners.

The GAFA, as Google, Amazon, Facebook and Apple are collectively called, also have good arguments on their side. If they are dominant, it is chiefly because consumers like their products. The four giants are an important engine of the American economy. That is why it would come as a surprise if America is ever as eager as the rest of the world to cut the giants down to size.

urn:contentItem:5STN-WW71-DY1K-81RT-00000-00Big technology is a big problem2018-07-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:22:56ZLexisNexisBig technology is a big problem

Big technology will be able to say that all the capital they put into new products and services is meant to drive innovation, but often the intention is to root out potential competition.

Have the technology giants - Amazon, Apple, Facebook, Google, and Microsoft- grown so big, rich and powerful that even regulators and politicians can not cope? The international investor community seems to think so, at least given the high stock market values ??of these companies. This is undoubtedly good news for the technology oligarchs, but is it for the economy?

Justice Be Made: In the last decades, the technology sector has been a source of pride and rejoicing in the US economy, being seen as a seemingly endless source of innovation. The speed and power of Google's search engine is breathtaking, putting an extraordinary amount of knowledge at our fingertips. Internet telephony allows friends, family, and co-workers to interact face-to-face from the other end of the world at a very modest cost.

However, despite all this innovation, the pace of productivity growth in the economy in general remains mediocre. Many economists describe the current situation as a &"second Solow moment,&" a reference to the 1987 remark by the legendary economist Robert Solow of MIT in 1987: &"We can see the information age everywhere, less productivity statistics.&"

There are many reasons for this slow growth in productivity, notably a decade of low investment following the global financial crisis of 2008. Still, we should be concerned that the five major technology companies have become so dominant, so profitable and so overwhelming that it has become very difficult for start-ups to challenge them, which ultimately stifles innovation. It is true that there was a time when Facebook and Google, when they were still newly-created companies, crushed Myspace and Yahoo. But that was before the market value of these companies jumped into the stratosphere, giving a huge financial advantage to entrenched players.

Thanks to the capital they have accumulated, great technology can absorb or crush any newcomer who wants to compete in any way. Admittedly, an intrepid young entrepreneur may reject an offer, but it is easier said than done. Not a lot of people are brave enough (or crazy enough) to reject today a $ 1 billion bid in hopes that they can do much more with their business later. And there is a risk that technology giants will resort to their vast armies of programmers to develop a virtually identical product - with vast legal resources to defend it.

Big techies may say that all the capital they put into new products and services is driving innovation, but often the intention is to root out potential competition. It is notable that large companies in the technology sector make the most of their revenue from their core products - such as Apple's iPhone, Microsoft Office and Google's search engine. Thus, in practice, potentially new disruptive technologies have the same possibilities of being buried or fed.

It is true that there are success stories. The extraordinary British artificial intelligence company DeepMind, which Google bought for $ 400 million in 2014, seems to be making headway in its field. DeepMind is famous for having developed the first Go programcapable of defeating the world champion of the specialty - a feat that is said to have prompted a Chinese army to begin a supreme effort to lead in the area of ??artificial intelligence. But in general, DeepMind seems to be an exception.

The problem for regulators is that conventional anti-monopoly structures do not apply in a world where costs to consumers (particularly in the form of data and privacy) are utterly opaque. But that's a poor excuse for not defying relatively obvious anti-competitive measures, such as when Facebook acquired Instagram (with its rapidly expanding social network) or when Google bought its competitor in the area of ??maps, Waze.

Perhaps the most pressing intervention is to weaken the control of our personal data by big technology, a control that allows Google and Facebook to develop targeted advertising tools that are getting hold of the marketing business. European regulators are showing a possible way forward, although US regulators are still stuck. The new EU General Data Protection Regulation now requires companies to allow customers - even if only those in the EU - to safeguard their data.

In their important recent book, Radical Markets, economists Glen Weyl and Eric Posner go further and argue that technology majors should pay for our data rather than claim it for their own use. Regardless of whether or not it is achievable, we should have the right to know what data companies record about us and how they are used.

Of course, Congress and US regulators also have to stop the big technology in many other key areas. As an example, the US Congress currently gives Internet-based companies a real free-for-all to enact false news. If we do not impose on the platforms of the great technological standards similar to those that are applied in the press, radio and television, there will be fewer and fewer in-depth reports and verification of the veracity of the information disseminated. And this is bad for both democracy and the economy.

Regulators and political leaders in the country that has given rise to the Internet need to agree. US prosperity has always depended on its ability to link economic growth to technology-driven innovation. But at the moment, big tech is much more of the problem than part of the solution.

Kenneth Rogoff, who was the IMF's chief economist, is a professor of economics and public policy at Harvard University.

Tech giants like Amazon and Facebook have lost sight of the people behind the data points. Antitrust regulation may be the best way to return empathy to tech. Big Tech CEOs—Amazon’s Jeff Bezos, Apple’s Tim Cook, Sundar Pichai of Google, and Facebook’s Mark...

Tech giants like Amazon and Facebook have lost sight of the people behind the data points. Antitrust regulation may be the best way to return empathy to tech. Big Tech CEOs—Amazon’s Jeff Bezos, Apple’s Tim Cook, Sundar Pichai of Google, and Facebook’s Mark Zuckerberg—testified yesterday before the U.S. House Judiciary antitrust subcommittee. I don’t expect much to result from this hearing. Such gatherings are largely theatrical, and yesterday’s was frequently derailed by partisan questions around liberal biases. And then there’s the fact that U.S. antitrust efforts are only a shadow of their former self, narrowly focused on consumer pricing rather than general competitive and societal impact and a far cry from the time of the Standard Oil Company, U.S. Steel Corporation, and AT&T breakups. urn:contentItem:5P9R-M601-JDJN-60Y5-00000-00Big Tech, Not Fintech, Causing Greatest Disruption To Banking And Insurance Markets2017-08-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:22:56ZLexisNexisBig Tech, Not Fintech, Causing Greatest Disruption To Banking And Insurance Markets

Financial institutions' drive to become more "experience-driven" is opening the door to potential competition from global technology giants, according to a report published by the World Economic Forum.

According to the report, Beyond Fintech: A Pragmatic Assessment of Disruptive Potential in Financial Services, the challenge to banks and insurers is down to large technology firms hollowing out the value proposition of these institutions by carrying out more core functions, even as banks and insurers lean ever more heavily on them to compete.

Another finding of the report, which aims to examine the impact of innovation on the financial ecosystem, is that fintech start-ups, while achieving success in terms of changing the basis for competition, have had less impact than expected in disrupting the competitive landscape.

"The partnership between banks and large tech companies risks not staying a reciprocal one," said Jesse McWaters, lead author of the study, and Project Lead, Disruptive Innovation in Financial Services at the World Economic Forum. "Financial institutions increasingly rely on technology firms for their most strategically sensitive capabilities, but can so far only offer their ongoing business in return."

The report draws on interviews and workshops with hundreds of financial and technology experts. It highlights cloud computing, customer-facing artificial intelligence and "big data" customer analytics as three capabilities that are becoming critical to the competitive differentiation of financial institutions. All three are domains where technology giants like Amazon, Google and Facebook have far deeper experience than their financial services counterparts and where scale effects will make it difficult for financial institutions to catch up. As a result, many banks and insurers are turning to technology firms to provide these core functions.

Examples include:

Amazon Web Services (AWS), which provides services to dozens of finance companies, including Aon, Capital One, Carlyle, Nasdaq, Pacific Life and Stripe
Brazil's Banco Bradesco Facebook app, which allows customers to conduct day-to-day banking from Facebook, relying on the social network's customer data analytics to target users
Capital One and Liberty Mutual's "Alexa" solution (a voice-activated personal assistant), which allows customers to check balances, pay bills and track spending through these devices

While these partnerships can accelerate innovation, the report points out that they also pose a risk should large technology players choose to enter financial services in direct competition with retail banks and insurers.

"Tech giants would be able to pick and choose their points of entry into financial services; maximizing their strengths like rich datasets and strong brands, while taking advantage of incumbent institutions' dependence on them," said McWaters. As a result, financial institutions will likely need to walk a challenging line between capitalizing on the services of large technology players and becoming dependent on them.

For customers, the entry of large technology firms into financial services could mean entrusting both their financial and non-financial data to the same company. For policy-makers it would raise serious questions about how best to avoid both anticompetitive behaviour and the inappropriate use of personal data in decision-making.

The findings suggest a move away from a focus on the potential competitive threat of high-tech financial services start-ups, typically called "fintechs". Much research, including the World Economic Forum's 2015 report on The Future of Financial Services, suggested that "niche" fintechs could stage a broader disruption of the financial system. But, while they have deeply influenced the direction of innovation in the industry, there are growing doubts about their ability to directly challenge incumbent financial institutions.

"Fintechs have changed the basis of competition in financial services, but not the competitive landscape" said Rob Galaski, Partner, Americas FSI Regional Leader, Deloitte Canada, and co-author of the report. "Fintechs now define the tempo and direction of innovation in financial services, but high customer switching costs and the rapid response of incumbents has challenged their ability to scale".

Robo-advisers, which provide automated investment advice to customers at low fees, provide an instructive example of incumbents responding to fintech. Early innovators like Betterment and Wealthfront have shown significant growth, with assets under management of $6.7 billion and $4.4 billion, respectively, at the end of 2016. However, they have been dwarfed by incumbents that have created their own robo-advisory offerings, such as the Vanguard Advisor platform, which had $47 billion in assets under management as of the end of 2016.

"The ability to be a fast follower has proven more important than being first for large financial institutions," said Galaski. "Agile incumbents have used the fintech ecosystem as a supermarket for capabilities, making the ability to nurture and rapidly form partnerships a critical ingredient to banks' competitive success."

Another of the report's findings notes the emergence of distinct financial systems in China, Europe and the United States, raising concerns for international regulatory coordination. The report observed that, in China, large technology companies like Ant Financial (a subsidiary of Alibaba) and Tencent (the parent company of WeChat) have emerged as leading providers of a range of financial services – a striking departure from the traditional bank-led model dominant in the United States.

Meanwhile in Europe, the forthcoming enactment of the Second Payment Services Directive (more commonly called PSDII) is expected to open up banks' customer data, creating an environment of more active competition between incumbents and new entrants.

"Technology is not driving a global convergence in customer experience, instead divergent customer demand and regulatory priorities are creating distinctly regionalized financial ecosystems" said Bob Contri, Principal, Deloitte Consulting LLP (US); Deloitte Global Financial Services Industry Leader, and an adviser to the report. "This could pose a serious challenge to regulatory coordination, as regulators struggle to understand the disparate impact of global regulations on each region".

urn:contentItem:5R29-9W91-JC8G-9407-00000-00Big Tech Not Primed for Breakup, AEI Panelists Say2017-11-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:22:56ZLexisNexisINDUSTRY NOTESBig Tech Not Primed for Breakup, AEI Panelists Say

It isn't clear whether large platform companies pose a distinct enough threat to merit antitrust action, but more regulation could be an option, said panelists during an American Enterprise Institute discussion Monday. "Some intervention is needed," said University of Chicago economist Luigi Zingales.

The concentration of advertising platforms is probably harmful for the economy, but a government-driven solution "isn't the right approach," he said. To evaluate whether there's market dominance, "you need to know whether a person can easily switch between services, and is there a cost to switching," and in today's tech market, consumers mostly have options, Zingales said. "What's happening in Silicon Valley is fantastic," agreed AEI Director-Economic Policy Studies Michael Strain. "The only thing that matters in antitrust analysis is consumer welfare, whether consumers are benefiting." Companies like Yahoo and RIM (now BlackBerry) that once were powerhouses no longer pose the same concerns, and have been overtaken by today's platform giants, he said. "It's foolish to think that it's impossible the iPhone won't be replaced by another device in 10 years. And I don't believe Google has perfected the way to organize the internet," Strain said. "The barrier to entry is pretty small," said Ryan Hagemann, Niskanen Center director-technology policy, making the case that a new entrant could challenge established players given the speed of tech innovation. "History is full of giants that eventually die," said Zingales.

urn:contentItem:5WND-2YT1-DY19-C1FF-00000-00Big Tech not so special after all2019-07-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:22:56ZLexisNexisBig Tech not so special after allJohn Davidson

The ACCC's latest recommendations are one more sign the era of of Big Tech getting special regulatory treatment is coming to an end.

On Wednesday, the US Securities and Exchange Commission levied a massive, $US100 million fine against Facebook, for misleading investors over the risks associated with data breaches.

The fine, part of the fallout of Facebook's Cambridge Analytica scandal, was remarkable in only one sense: for something with a $US100 million ($144 million) price tag, it was thoroughly unremarkable.

That same day, the US Federal Trade Commission also fined Facebook fifty times as much for the same scandal, a record $US5 billion, and forced the social media company to institute systemic changes so it finally might make good on previous undertakings to fix its privacy settings.

Also that same day, Facebook announced that it was being investigated by the FTC for antitrust violations.

The day earlier, the US Department of Justice said that it was conducting an anti-trust review of Big Tech, looking to see whether companies such as Google, Facebook, Amazon and Apple were abusing their market power.

All this came on top of a ???1.5 billion ($2.4 billion) fine in March, and another ???4.3 billion fine last June, levied against Google by the European Union for various antitrust abuses.

It's a sign of an industry in permanent crisis when a $US100 million fine seems like the very least of its woes.

And this week, Big Tech's permanent crisis came to Canberra.

ACCC steps in

On Friday, the federal government released the long-awaited findings of the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission's 18-month-long Digital Platforms Inquiry - one of the first regulatory inquiries in the world to investigate the market power of the online platforms Google and Facebook, with respect to their influence on the media and advertising landscape.

The ACCC found that, despite Google's and Facebook's protestations that they don't have market power due to the range of alternatives available to consumers, the two companies do indeed wield considerable market power.

Its final Digital Platforms Inquiry report recommended a range of measures to curb that power, including the formation of a new division inside the ACCC that would have the power to oversee the algorithms Google, Facebook and other tech companies use to shape the way advertising and news reaches the public.

It recommended that Google be forced to change the settings on phones running its Android platform, so that consumers can more readily change the default browser away from Google's Chrome, and the default search engine away from google.com.

It recommended a code of conduct that would govern the way platforms such as Facebook handle complaints about fake news.

And it recommended Australia strengthen its privacy laws, placing strictures on the way the tech giants can capture information from the public, and forcing the giants to erase personal information "without undue delay" when requested to do so by a member of the public.

"The market power of these companies is immense," said Treasurer Josh Frydenberg, announcing the findings of the ACCC inquiry.

"The world has never seen so much data collected and aggregated among two companies.

"Our legislative and regulatory framework could not and did not anticipate such a new paradigm: a paradigm which poses real challenges for authorities the world over," he said.

What's at stake

At stake are nearly $9 billion in online advertising revenues, the lion's share of which go to Facebook and Google.

"For every $100 spent by advertisers on online advertising, excluding classifieds, $47 goes to Google, $24 to Facebook and $29 to other participants," Frydenberg said.

At stake, too, is the influence which those platforms have on the way Australians consume their news, and on the very news they consume.

In its final report, the ACCC cited the findings of a Nielsen Digital Panel from February, which looked at how Australians across all demographics spent their time looking at the internet on phones, tablets and PCs.

More than one fifth of time, some 2.5 per cent, was spent looking at Google. Another 18.5 per cent of time was devoted to Facebook's various apps, including WhatsApp, Instagram and Facebook Messenger.

Only 2.3 per cent of time was spent on all major news outlets combined, including Ten, Seven West, News Corp, ABC and Nine, which publishes AFR Weekend.

"Australian society, like others around the world, has been impacted by disinformation and a rising mistrust of news," the ACCC said in a statement.

"The dominant digital platforms' response to the issues we have raised might best be described as ???trust us'," ACCC chair Rod Sims said.

But there's something else at stake, too. Something more fundamental.

It's the very way tech companies are perceived in the world, and how they are taxed and regulated as a result.

The ACCC's inquiry, along with the investigations announced this week in the US, asks the question that Big Tech has been trying to avoid since its emergence as a dominant social and economic force in the 1990s.

A question of perception

Should technology companies be treated for what they say they are, or for what they actually are?

Tech companies such as Google, Facebook, Uber and Airbnb want to be treated as software platforms, as something essentially new in the annals of business, that gets regulated and taxed in a new way: one which happens to suit their bottom line.

Uber, for instance, argues it's not a taxi or transport company, but rather claims it's simply an app that helps drivers and passengers connect to each other, allowing it to avoid regulations that usually might apply to transport companies.

Facebook, meanwhile, argues it's not a publisher, and for that reason shouldn't be held to the same standards that other publishers are held to. Laws such as copyright and defamation, which restrict the activities of traditional publishers, either shouldn't apply at all to Facebook, or should apply in only a very limited way.

But, increasingly, regulators around the world have been calling for them to be treated for what they really are: advertising companies, or transport companies, or in Airbnb's case, a property agent.

In December 2017, the European Court of Justice ruled that Uber really was transport company, and not just a social app for people interested in sitting in cars.

That same month, the ACCC's Rod Sims made a similar case against Facebook and Google.

"They are essentially advertising companies. People think of them differently, but there's no question they're advertising companies, they're trying to tailor their product to advertisers," he told The Australian Financial Review.

Since then, the regulatory tide has been turning against Big Tech.

In May 2018, the European Union's General Data Protection Regulation came into effect, putting limits on the way the tech giants could handle the billions of pieces of information they have collated on the world's population. The new regime also gave people the right to review that information, or have it removed.

The following February, regulators in German, emboldened by the GDPR, ordered Facebook to separate its Facebook, Instagram and WhatsApp apps from each other, despite Facebook's protestations that it's an Irish company for purposes of the GDPR, and should be regulated as such.

And then, in March this year, Facebook live-streamed the gunning down of 100 people in Christchurch, New Zealand, killing 51, in what the terrorist described as a "real effort" social media post.

New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern addressed her parliament.

"There cannot be the case of all profit, no responsibility," Ardern said.

"They are the publisher, not just the postman," she said.

The era of Big Tech getting special regulatory treatment had come to an end.

What now?

One of the ACCC's 23 recommendations called for a "harmonisation" of Australia's media regulatory framework, so that Big Tech companies such as Netflix no longer get treated as something inherently different from other media companies which do essentially the same thing.

Communications Minister Paul Fletcher, who helped launch the ACCC findings alongside Frydenberg, provided an example of how things are set to change for Big Tech.

"Free-to-air television networks face regulatory obligations to show a certain amount of Australian content and to pay for that as do subscription television platforms. But there are no such obligations on internet-based video streaming services.

"The ACCC recommends that there's a need to develop a harmonised media regulatory framework to deal with these issues and this is something the government accepts," he said.

Whether that's something Big Tech will accept, though, remains to be seen.

Big Tech argues for special treatment

Digi, the peak body representing US technology companies including Google, Facebook and Twitter, on Friday called on the Australian government to assess the ACCC's recommendations against an "innovation test".

The test would examine how the ACCC's recommendation would "impact Australia's digital industry at large and Australia's global standing as a place to invest in technology," Digi said.

But an innovation test, which by its very definition would seek to treat a company or an industry differently because it was doing something new, is the very thing that regulators around the world have spent the last two years trying to wind back.

Uber, the European Court of Justice found in 2017, might be something new, but that's no reason not to treat it the same as an old-fashioned transport company.

Google, as Sims said, might be doing something new in the way it sells ads, but that's no reason not to treat it the same as an old-fashioned advertising company.

And, besides, not everything that's new is desirable. A terrorist live-streaming the massacre of 51 New Zealanders was an innovation that not even Facebook wants repeated.

Not all innovation is progress.
